gamma.name: gamma
gamma.info:
iOS and iPadOS devices usually have screens with a gamma value around 2.2.
You can "correct" this gamma value if you want the luminance values to be linear.

durationProperty.name: duration
durationProperty.info: Duration of the stimulus. By default is set to 1000 seconds.

startProperty.name: start
startProperty.info: Time at which the stimulus begins, measured from the start of the scene.

originProperty.name: originCoordinates
originProperty.info: By default, the origin of coordinates is placed in the center of the screen, but it is possible to place it in another point of the screen.

properties.name: size
properties.info: The size of the shape containing the stimulus.

activatedProperty.name: activated
activatedProperty.info:
Boolean variable that establishes whether the stimulus is active or not.
Useful when you have stimuli that should be presented in some trials and not presented in other trials.
Use this variable to control the presence of the stimulus rather than using contrast = 0 or volume = 0 or other workarounds.
Making the stimulus inactive is the only way to make sure nor CPU neither GPU cycles are used to compute the stimulus.

positionProperty.name: position
positionProperty.info:
Position of the center of the stimulus relative to the origin of coordinates.
X increases from left to right and Y increases from bottom to top.
The angles are measured counterclockwise from the x axis.

rotationProperty.name: rotation
rotationProperty.info:
The angle of rotation of the stimulus (both the shape and its content).
Measured counterclockwise.

properties.name: contrastValue
properties.info: Maximum value of the contrast in the center of the stimulus.

properties.name: contrastValueStartMovement
properties.info: The time in which the movement starts.

properties.name: contrastValueCenter
properties.info: Time in which the result reaches the maximum value.

properties.name: contrastValueDeviation
properties.info: Standard deviation of the gauss function.

properties.name: contrastGaussianDeviation
properties.info: The standard deviation of the gaussian function of the contrast.

modulatorProperty.name: modulator
modulatorProperty.info: Modulator of the contrast of the stimulus.

properties.name: period
properties.info: Size period of the sinusoidal function.

properties.name: phaseStartMovement
properties.info: The time in which the movement starts.

properties.name: phaseSpeed
properties.info: Linear increase of value with time.

properties.name: gratingRotation
properties.info: Orientation of the grating. This property only rotates the grating but not the shape that masks it.

name.name: name
name.info: A name to identify this stimulus.

durationProperty.name: duration
durationProperty.info: Duration of the stimulus. By default is set to 1000 seconds.

startProperty.name: start
startProperty.info: Time at which the stimulus begins, measured from the start of the scene.

originProperty.name: originCoordinates
originProperty.info: By default, the origin of coordinates is placed in the center of the screen, but it is possible to place it in another point of the screen.

properties.name: length
properties.info: The length of the cross sides.

properties.name: thickness
properties.info: The thickness of the cross strokes.

name.name: name

numberOfLayers.name: numberOfLayers
numberOfLayers.info:
The number of layers in the scene.
By default, all objects are drawn on the same layer, which is drawn on top of the background.
If you want to draw one object on top of another, you must increase the number of layers.
(This does not apply to video or text objects that are rendered differently, always on top of everything).

When drawing objects, a preassigned space is saved for each one of them.
This space is slightly larger than the object itself.
If two objects are too close to each other, their respective preassigned spaces can interfere, creating an unwanted empty space between the objects.
To avoid this, you should increase the number of layers (or separate the objects a bit if possible).

Increasing the number of layers is computationally costly, so try to use as few layers as possible, especially when working at 120Hz.

continuousResolution.name: continuousResolution
continuousResolution.info:
When using stimuliApp, images are displayed in an sRGB space with 256 possible values for each channel of the RGB color.
If you are working only with luminances: R = G = B, there are 256 luminance levels.

Sometimes this limitation on the number of different luminance intensities displayable can be an issue.
By making the continuosResolution property true, the noisy-bit method is implemented.
This method consists of adding a small amount of random noise.
The method is described in Allard, R., Faubert, J., 2008. The Noisy-Bit method for digital displays: Converting a 256 luminance resolution into a continuous resolution. Behav. Res. Methods 40, 735–743.

The noisy-bit method, combined with the 256 luminance levels, is perceptually equivalent to an analog display with a continuous luminance intensity resolution when the spatiotemporal resolution is high enough that the noise becomes negligible.

responseType.name: response
responseType.info:
To select one of the possible types of responses for the scene.

Each time a response is given the scene ends even if the time has not reached the duration of the scene.

durationType.name: duration
durationType.info: The maximum duration of the scene if no response is given.

name.info: A name to identify this object.

responseType.name: response
responseType.info:
To select one of the possible types of responses for the scene.

Each time a response is given the scene ends even if the time has not reached the duration of the scene.

properties.name: startTime
properties.info:
Time from which it is possible to respond.
By default it is zero, the user can respond at any time.

properties.name: endTime
properties.info: Maximum time until which it is possible to respond.

properties.name: wrongTiming
properties.info:
If 0 it is not possible to respond before startTime or after endTime.
If 1 it is possible to respond before startTime or after endTime but the response is considered incorrect.

properties.name: leftValue
properties.info: Numeric value for the left response.

properties.name: rightValue
properties.info: Numeric value for the right response.

durationType.name: duration
durationType.info: The maximum duration of the scene if no response is given.

name.info: A name to identify this object.

next.name: when all the section trials have been performed
next.info:
The order of the conditions in the menu is the order in which they are evaluated.

If a condition is true, the action associated with that condition will be performed and the following conditions will not be evaluated.

The possible actions that can be performed are to go to another section or to end the test.

If neither condition is true, a new trial in the same section is performed.

repetitions.name: repetitions
repetitions.info: The number of repetitions of all the different trials.

name.name: name
name.info: A name to identify this section.

numberOfLayers.name: numberOfLayers
numberOfLayers.info:
The number of layers in the scene.
By default, all objects are drawn on the same layer, which is drawn on top of the background.
If you want to draw one object on top of another, you must increase the number of layers.
(This does not apply to video or text objects that are rendered differently, always on top of everything).

When drawing objects, a preassigned space is saved for each one of them.
This space is slightly larger than the object itself.
If two objects are too close to each other, their respective preassigned spaces can interfere, creating an unwanted empty space between the objects.
To avoid this, you should increase the number of layers (or separate the objects a bit if possible).

Increasing the number of layers is computationally costly, so try to use as few layers as possible, especially when working at 120Hz.

continuousResolution.name: continuousResolution
continuousResolution.info:
When using stimuliApp, images are displayed in an sRGB space with 256 possible values for each channel of the RGB color.
If you are working only with luminances: R = G = B, there are 256 luminance levels.

Sometimes this limitation on the number of different luminance intensities displayable can be an issue.
By making the continuosResolution property true, the noisy-bit method is implemented.
This method consists of adding a small amount of random noise.
The method is described in Allard, R., Faubert, J., 2008. The Noisy-Bit method for digital displays: Converting a 256 luminance resolution into a continuous resolution. Behav. Res. Methods 40, 735–743.

The noisy-bit method, combined with the 256 luminance levels, is perceptually equivalent to an analog display with a continuous luminance intensity resolution when the spatiotemporal resolution is high enough that the noise becomes negligible.

responseType.name: response
responseType.info:
To select one of the possible types of responses for the scene.

Each time a response is given the scene ends even if the time has not reached the duration of the scene.

properties.name: startTime
properties.info:
Time from which it is possible to respond.
By default it is zero, the user can respond at any time.

properties.name: endTime
properties.info: Maximum time until which it is possible to respond.

properties.name: wrongTiming
properties.info:
If 0 it is not possible to respond before startTime or after endTime.
If 1 it is possible to respond before startTime or after endTime but the response is considered incorrect.

properties.name: originCoordinates
properties.info: By default, the center of the screen is the origin of coordinates but you can change the origin so that it is in any other point.

properties.name: position
properties.info: The response position, measured in cartesian or polar variables.

durationType.name: duration
durationType.info: The maximum duration of the scene if no response is given.

name.name: name
name.info: A name to identify this object.

name.name: name
name.info: A name to identify this object.

name.name: name
name.info: A name to identify this object.

name.name: name
name.info: A name to identify this object.

name.name: name
name.info: A name to identify this scene

next.name: when all the section trials have been performed
next.info:
The order of the conditions in the menu is the order in which they are evaluated.

If a condition is true, the action associated with that condition will be performed and the following conditions will not be evaluated.

The possible actions that can be performed are to go to another section or to end the test.

If neither condition is true, a new trial in the same section is performed.

repetitions.name: repetitions
repetitions.info: The number of repetitions of all the different trials.

name.name: name
name.info: A name to identify this section.

frameRate.name: frameRate
frameRate.info: On this device, the refresh rate of the screen is always 60 HZ.

cancelButtonPosition.name: XButton
cancelButtonPosition.info: The position on the screen of the button that is used to cancel test in progress.

distance.name: viewingDistance
distance.info:
Viewing distance from the participant to the screen.

This value is used to calculate the actual pixel size of any property that is measured in visual angle degrees.

brightness.name: luminance
brightness.info:
You can control the luminance of the screen with this parameter.

The perceived brightness is approximately proportional to the logarithm of the luminance that you set with this parameter.

The new luminance will only be effective once the test begins.

There are a few preferences on iOS and iPadOS that can automatically change the brightness and color temperature settings of the device:

Auto-Brightness can be found in your device Settings, Accessibility, Display & Text Size.

TrueTone and Night Shift options can be found in your device Settings, Display & Brightness.

Remember to disable these options to avoid unwanted changes of brightness when running a test.

Even with the Auto-Brightness adjustment disabled, the brightness of the device can be slightly increased automatically if you are under a bright light (outside).

firstSection.name: firstSection
firstSection.info: The first section of the test.

name.name: name
name.info: A name to identify this test.
